It's pretty easy.  Use apt-get and install ntp.  Open the config file and use the examples within, to peer with a few (at least 3) external time sources.  I think the package name is just, "ntp."

You may even be able to get away with using ntpdate to dicipline your clock but since ntpdate is sort of a, "one-shot" deal, you would have to call it on a regular basis (like maybe every 30 minutes, depending on the accuracy of your hwclock).

isn't it possible to have only 1 server being an NTP server, and the second one syncing from it? the reason is that i'm about 600 ms away from the world (slow satellite) with random delay of packets and the clock never gets right atomically because of that

The problem you will run into is this.  The time source (one of your boxes) will not have accurate time because it isn't peering with a reasonably low stratum source.  NTP is smart enough to know this and because of it, it will refuse to allow other sources to sync with it.
You could set one box to peer with external sources and then have your other box just peer with your first.  That should work fine too.
i have installed NTP on the first server; by "peering" do you mean this command: ntpdate 192.168.139.128 (address of the first server)
You configure it in ntp.conf, I believe.  ntpdate is just a command line utility for doing a, "one-shot" time sync with some source.
But like I said, ntpdate may work for you depending on how often you call it, and how accurate your hardware clock is.
If you need better than 10ms accuracy, I'd go strictly ntp.

So, in a nutshell, install ntp on the, "server" box and then configure it to peer with several external sources.  On the second box, either systematically call ntpdate <IP.OF.SERVER.BOX>, or just install ntp on it as well and configure it to peer with the server.
